```{r}
#| include: false

# I usually start with a setup chunk where I load library, read data, and set general options

library(tidyverse)
library(flextable)
library(rstatix)
library(papaja)
library(conflicted)
conflicts_prefer(purrr::discard)
conflicts_prefer(flextable::theme_apa)

theme_update(text = element_text(size = 12),
             axis.text.x = element_text(size = 12, color = "black"), 
             axis.title.x = element_text(size = 14),
             axis.text.y = element_text(size = 12,  color = "black"), 
             axis.title.y = element_text(size = 14), 
             panel.background = element_blank(),panel.border = element_blank(), 
             panel.grid.major = element_blank(),
             panel.grid.minor = element_blank(), axis.line = element_blank(), 
             axis.ticks.length=unit(.25, "cm"), 
             legend.key = element_rect(fill = "white")) 

ds <- read_csv("data/metrics.csv")

```

# Results

See @fig-metrics for more detail.

```{r}
#| label: fig-metrics
#| fig-cap: Figure title 
#| fig-width: 7.5 
#| fig-height: 6.5 
#| apa-note: Figure note 

ggplot(ds, aes(x = duration_actual, y = duration_predicted)) +
  geom_point() + geom_abline()
```

See @tbl-metrics for individual agreement statistics. Flextable is a nice package for formatting tables.

```{r}
#| label: tbl-metrics
#| tbl-cap: Table title 
#| fig-width: 7.5 
#| fig-height: 6.5 
#| tbl-note: Under table note

head(ds) %>% flextable() %>% theme_apa()
```

```{r}
#| label: correlation-stats
#| include: false

# When you need to refer to values in text, its nice to arrange them ahead of time
# Analysis chunks like these can help gather your stats before you need to write about them
duration_cor <- cor_test(ds, duration_actual, duration_predicted)
duration_r <- apa_num(duration_cor$cor) 
duration_p <- apa_p(duration_cor$p) 
```

Actual and predicted durations were strongly correlated, *r*(`r nrow(ds)-2`) = `r duration_r`, *p* `r duration_p`.
